docs.lead_paragraph: In the horror movie “Jessabelle,” a woman returns to her childhood home to recover from a car accident and finds unsettling videotapes of her mother telling fortunes.

headline.seo: ‘Jessabelle’: From Tragic Car Wreck to Haunted House
headline.main: Scratch Baths From the Recovery Regimen

docs.abstract: Ben Kenigsberg reviews movie Jessabelle, directed by Kevin Greutert and starring Sarah Snook.
docs.snippet: In the horror movie “Jessabelle,” a woman returns to her childhood home to recover from a car accident and finds unsettling videotapes of her mother telling fortunes.

headline.main: An Oklahoma Court’s Good Move on Abortion Rights

docs.abstract: The Oklahoma Supreme Court blocked enforcement of two egregious new laws designed to make it more difficult than it already is for women to obtain safe and legal abortions.
docs.snippet: The Oklahoma Supreme Court blocked enforcement of two egregious new laws designed to make it more difficult than it already is for women to obtain safe and legal abortions.

docs.lead_paragraph: There are some positive ways to interpret the midterms. You just have to look for them.

headline.seo: Finding Good News in the Election Results
headline.main: Always Look on the Bright Side
headline.print_headline: Always Look on the Bright Side

docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column advocates for looking on the post-election bright side; suggests there are some positive ways to interpret the midterm elections, one just has to look for them; points out there is school of thought that believes elections were actually a great day for reproductive rights.
docs.snippet: There are some positive ways to interpret the midterms. You just have to look for them.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican victory was the result of methodical plotting, careful candidate vetting and an abundance of preparation to ensure the party’s candidates would avoid repeating the same mistakes.

headline.main: Republicans’ First Step Was to Handle Extremists in Party
headline.print_headline: Republicans First Had to Wrestle With Their Own Poor Discipline

docs.abstract: Republicans' impressive showing in midterm elections is the result of methodical plotting, careful candidate vetting and abundant preparation to ensure party’s candidates would avoid repeating same mistakes that cost them dearly in 2010 and 2012; election unfolded during perhaps the best political climate for its party that GOP has seen since 1980s.
docs.snippet: The Republican victory was the result of methodical plotting, careful candidate vetting and an abundance of preparation to ensure the party’s candidates would avoid repeating the same mistakes.

byline.original: By JEREMY W. PETERS and CARL HULSE

docs.lead_paragraph: You two haven’t been so well acquainted. In the new, post-midterms Congress, is there hope for a more respectful relationship?
docs.abstract: Frank Bruni Op-Ed column expresses hope that Republicans will begin to show more respect for science, particularly regarding climate change, when they take control of the Senate; contends with proper fealty to science, the next Congress would be forced to accept overwhelming consensus on climate change and take action.
docs.snippet: You two haven’t been so well acquainted. In the new, post-midterms Congress, is there hope for a more respectful relationship?

docs.lead_paragraph: The court voted to prevent enforcement of the new abortion measures pending the outcome of lawsuits challenging their constitutionality.

headline.main: Oklahoma Supreme Court Blocks 2 Abortion Laws
headline.print_headline: Oklahoma Supreme Court Blocks 2 Abortion Laws

docs.abstract: Oklahoma Supreme Court blocks two new laws that critics say may have made it difficult for women to obtain abortions in the state; votes in unanimous decision to prevent enforcement of the rules until lawsuits challenging their constitutionality are settled by a lower court.
docs.snippet: The court voted to prevent enforcement of the new abortion measures pending the outcome of lawsuits challenging their constitutionality.

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical companies are looking for a technology that takes only a little blood, and gives an answer in minutes instead of hours or days.

headline.main: Researchers Seek Crucial Tool: A Fast, Finger-Prick Ebola Test
headline.print_headline: Researchers Seek Crucial Tool: A Fast, Finger-Prick Ebola Test

docs.abstract: Medical companies and academic researchers, searching for new ways to attack Ebola, are racing to develop faster and easier tests for the virus; they are looking for a technology that takes only a little blood, and gives an answer in minutes instead of hours or days.
docs.snippet: Medical companies are looking for a technology that takes only a little blood, and gives an answer in minutes instead of hours or days.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The Air Force has fired or disciplined at least 16 nuclear missile commanders or senior officers for misconduct and other failings over the past year and a half, reflecting turmoil in arguably the military's most sensitive mission.

headline.main: Disciplinary Acts Against Nuke Officers Topped 16
headline.print_headline: Disciplinary Acts Against Nuke Officers Topped 16

docs.snippet: The Air Force has fired or disciplined at least 16 nuclear missile commanders or senior officers for misconduct and other failings over the past year and a half, reflecting turmoil in arguably the military's most sensitive mission.

docs.lead_paragraph: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, November 4, 2014.
docs.snippet: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, November 4, 2014.

docs.lead_paragraph: Col. Carl Jones, the No. 2 commander of the 90th Missile Wing at F. E. Warren Air Force Base, Wyo., was dismissed for “a loss of trust and confidence in his leadership abilities,” and has been reassigned.
docs.abstract: Air Force fires two nuclear commanders and disciplines third; Col Carl Jones, the No 2 commander of the 90th Missile Wing at F E Warren Air Force Base, Wyo, is dismissed for 'a loss of trust and confidence in his leadership abilities,' and is reassigned.
docs.snippet: Col. Carl Jones, the No. 2 commander of the 90th Missile Wing at F. E. Warren Air Force Base, Wyo., was dismissed for “a loss of trust and confidence in his leadership abilities,” and has been reassigned.
